BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and strong wind. Small and medium-sized natural avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes storm force wind from southwesterly directions, avalanche prone wind slabs will form. They can be released even by a single winter sport participant. Mostly the avalanches are medium-sized. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep slopes above approximately 2000 m, and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

As a consequence of the heavy snowfall individual natural loose snow slides are possible as the day progresses, even medium-sized ones. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided. This applies in particular on steep grassy slopes in all aspects especially above the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 40 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 2000 m. The sometimes storm force wind will transport the new snow significantly. The fresh wind slabs will be deposited on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack in all aspects in all altitude zones. Towards its base, the snowpack consists of faceted crystals.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In some regions 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Saturday. Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Small and medium-sized natural avalanches are possible.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Significant increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and wind. In the course of the day danger level 3 (considerable) will be reached in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation above approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs that are being formed by the southerly wind will become increasingly prone to triggering. This applies in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
In particular at intermediate and high altitudes large natural avalanches are possible. In the regions exposed to a lot of new snow this applies especially.
The new snow and wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, above approximately 2000 m, caution is to be exercised in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 30 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1800 m. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on the smooth surface of an old snowpack. This applies in particular at intermediate and high altitudes and along the border with Switzerland.
These weather conditions as the day progresses will give rise to unfavourable bonding of the snowpack.
The snowpack will become unstable over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area new snow to below approximately 1500 m. The avalanche danger will increase.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The old snowpack will be in most cases well bonded. As a consequence of new snow and strong wind the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase as the day progresses. On steep slopes and on wind-loaded slopes dry slab avalanches are possible as the day progresses, even quite large ones.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be generally well bonded. Weak layers exist in the top section of the old snowpack especially on very steep shady slopes. The new snow and wind slabs can be released easily or naturally in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2200 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
New snow and wind slabs can in some places be released by a single winter sport participant and reach medium size. In the regions exposed to a lot of new snow this applies especially above approximately 2200 m and.
In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation avalanches are possible, but they can be large in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 2200 m. The new snow will be deposited on bare ground over a wide area, in particular on sunny slopes and at low and intermediate altitudes.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on the smooth surface of an old snowpack. This applies especially at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions, along the border with France.
Towards its surface, the snowpack is soft and has a loosely bonded surface. The snowfall will give rise as the day progresses to unfavourable bonding of the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area new snow. The avalanche danger will increase.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and strong wind. Mostly small natural avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes storm force wind from southwesterly directions, avalanche prone wind slabs will form. They can be released even by a single winter sport participant. Mostly the avalanches are medium-sized. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep slopes above approximately 2000 m, and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

As a consequence of the heavy snowfall individual natural loose snow slides are possible as the day progresses, even medium-sized ones. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided. This applies in particular on steep grassy slopes in all aspects especially above the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 40 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 2000 m. The sometimes storm force wind will transport the new snow significantly. The fresh wind slabs will be deposited on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack in all aspects in all altitude zones.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In some regions 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Saturday. Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Small and medium-sized natural avalanches are possible.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and strong wind.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes storm force wind from southwesterly directions, avalanche prone wind slabs will form. They can be released even by a single winter sport participant. Mostly the avalanches are medium-sized. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on shady slopes above approximately 2000 m, especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

Individual gliding avalanches are possible, in particular medium-sized ones. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided. This applies in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1400 m. The sometimes storm force wind will transport the new snow significantly. The fresh wind slabs will be deposited on soft layers in particular on steep shady slopes above the tree line. Towards its base, the snowpack consists of faceted crystals.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In some regions 10 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Saturday. Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. A latent danger of gliding avalanches exists.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow to low altitudes: Gradual increase in danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
New snow and wind slabs can in some places be released by a single winter sport participant and reach medium size, in the regions exposed to a lot of new snow especially above approximately 2000 m and.
In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation avalanches are possible, but they can be large in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 15 to 25 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1800 m. The new snow will be deposited on bare ground over a wide area, in particular on sunny slopes and at low and intermediate altitudes.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on the smooth surface of an old snowpack. This applies especially at intermediate and high altitudes, along the border with France.
Towards its surface, the snowpack is soft and has a loosely bonded surface. The snowfall will give rise as the day progresses to unfavourable bonding of the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area a lot of new snow to below approximately 1600 m. The avalanche danger will increase.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and strong wind.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes storm force wind from southwesterly directions, avalanche prone wind slabs will form. They can be released even by a single winter sport participant. Mostly the avalanches are medium-sized. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep slopes above approximately 2000 m, and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

As a consequence of the heavy snowfall individual natural loose snow slides are possible as the day progresses, even medium-sized ones. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided. This applies in particular on steep grassy slopes in all aspects especially above the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 10 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 2000 m. The sometimes storm force wind will transport the new snow significantly. The fresh wind slabs will be deposited on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack in all aspects in all altitude zones. Towards its base, the snowpack consists of faceted crystals.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In some regions 15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Saturday. Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow represents the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The old snowpack will be generally well bonded. The new snow and wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence on steep north, northeast and northwest facing slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: On shady slopes and on wind-loaded slopes the avalanche danger will increase during the day to level 2 (moderate).

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and wind.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Friday above approximately 1400 m.
Near the border with France and along the border with Switzerland the likelihood of avalanches is higher. If more snow falls danger level 3 (considerable) may be reached in the afternoon.
The sometimes strong wind will transport the new snow. The mostly small wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant.
In regions exposed to heavier precipitation the avalanche prone locations are more widespread. These avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
Small and medium-sized natural avalanches are possible in particular on wind-loaded slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Little snow fell on Thursday along the border with France and along the border with Switzerland. 5 to 15 cm of snow, but less in some localities, has fallen above approximately 2000 m.
The new snow and wind slabs will be deposited on a weakly bonded old snowpack on rather lightly snow-covered shady slopes. Will be deposited on a crust on steep south, west and southeast facing slopes.
Below approximately 2200 m only a little snow is lying on south and southwest facing slopes. Above the tree line snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Increase in avalanche danger as the snowfall becomes more intense.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and wind.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Friday above approximately 1400 m.
Near the border with France and along the border with Switzerland the likelihood of avalanches is higher. If more snow falls danger level 3 (considerable) may be reached in the afternoon.
The sometimes strong wind will transport the new snow. The mostly small wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant.
In regions exposed to heavier precipitation the avalanche prone locations are more widespread. These avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
Small and medium-sized natural avalanches are possible in particular on wind-loaded slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Little snow fell on Thursday along the border with France and along the border with Switzerland. 5 to 15 cm of snow, but less in some localities, has fallen above approximately 2000 m.
The new snow and wind slabs will be deposited on a weakly bonded old snowpack on rather lightly snow-covered shady slopes. Will be deposited on a crust on steep south, west and southeast facing slopes.
Below approximately 2200 m only a little snow is lying on south and southwest facing slopes. Above the tree line snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Increase in avalanche danger as the snowfall becomes more intense.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence. A latent danger of gliding avalanches exists.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
At elevated altitudes sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs will form. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2000 m. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. In localities where more snow falls the avalanche danger is greater.

Individual gliding avalanches are possible, in particular medium-sized ones. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided. This applies in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area up to 20 cm of snow, and up to 25 cm in some localities, will fall on Friday above approximately 1500 m. The strong wind will transport the new snow. The fresh wind slabs will be deposited on soft layers in particular on shady slopes.

The old snowpack is largely stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Some snow will fall on Saturday in some regions. The wind will be strong over a wide area. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are to be assessed with care and prudence. A latent danger of gliding avalanches exists.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and strong wind.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes storm force wind from southwesterly directions, avalanche prone wind slabs will form. They can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases. In some cases avalanches are medium-sized. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on shady slopes above approximately 2000 m, especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

Individual gliding avalanches are possible, but they will be mostly small. This applies in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 5 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1400 m. The sometimes storm force wind will transport the new snow significantly. The fresh wind slabs will be deposited on soft layers in particular on steep shady slopes above the tree line. Towards its base, the snowpack consists of faceted crystals.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In some regions 10 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Saturday. Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
Over a wide area heavy precipitation.
The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase in the afternoon.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As the day progresses as the precipitation becomes more intense there will be an increase in the avalanche danger to level 2 (moderate).
The new snow must be evaluated with care and prudence. This snow can be released in isolated cases, but mostly only by large additional loads in all aspects. Small and medium-sized avalanches are to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area new snow above the tree line.
Over a wide area only a little snow is lying on south facing slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
The weather report and anticipated change in the avalanche danger are uncertain.
Over a wide area heavy precipitation.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
Over a wide area heavy precipitation.
The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase in the afternoon.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As the day progresses as the precipitation becomes more intense there will be an increase in the avalanche danger to level 2 (moderate).
The new snow must be evaluated with care and prudence. This snow can be released in isolated cases, but mostly only by large additional loads in all aspects. Small and medium-sized avalanches are to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area new snow above the tree line.
Over a wide area only a little snow is lying on south facing slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
The weather report and anticipated change in the avalanche danger are uncertain.
Over a wide area heavy precipitation.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Old wind slabs in particular adjacent to ridgelines in all aspects. Distinct weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack can be released in isolated cases even by individual winter sport participants in particular on steep shady slopes. This applies in particular in little used terrain, as well as in areas where the snow cover is rather shallow above the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be prone to triggering in some places. This applies in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2000 m. Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted and weak.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The covering of new snow is homogeneous.
